description: 30 days of Swahili micro-lessons: 3 words + 1 sentence + 1 tip + 1 culture note per day.

words.sentence: Habari za leo? — How are you today?
Nzuri sana. — Very good.
Asante kwa msaada. — Thank you for the help.

days.tip: Swahili vowels are consistent: a=ah, e=eh, i=ee, o=oh, u=oo. Say them clean and steady.
days.culture: Greetings matter. Taking time to ask “Habari?” shows respect and warmth in many East African communities.

words.sentence: Tafadhali nisaidie. — Please help me.
Samahani, naweza kupita? — Excuse me, may I pass?
Karibu nyumbani. — Welcome home.

days.tip: The “dh” sound (as in tafadhali) is like “th” in “this.” Don’t turn it into a hard “d.”
days.culture: “Karibu” is used constantly: welcoming guests, inviting someone closer, or responding to thanks (“you’re welcome”).

words.sentence: Huyu ni rafiki yangu. — This is my friend.
Ninaipenda familia yangu. — I love my family.
Mwalimu anafundisha darasani. — The teacher teaches in class.

days.tip: Swahili often uses “ni” = I am, “huyu” = this person, “yangu” = my. You’ll see these a lot.
days.culture: Community identity is strong—words like “rafiki” and “familia” reflect social bonds and shared responsibility.

words.sentence: Nina kitabu kimoja. — I have one book.
Tuna watu wawili. — We have two people.
Nataka matunda matatu. — I want three fruits.

days.tip: “mb” starts together as one sound, like in “ambition” but stronger at the start: mbili.
days.culture: Counting and bargaining in markets is common—numbers become practical fast.

words.sentence: Leo nina kazi. — Today I have work.
Kesho tutakutana. — Tomorrow we will meet.
Jana nilisafiri. — Yesterday I traveled.

days.tip: Keep the vowels open and pure—don’t swallow the ending vowel.
days.culture: Swahili has its own time-telling system in many regions; for now, these day-words are universal and super useful.

words.sentence: Chakula hiki ni kitamu. — This food is delicious.
Nahitaji maji. — I need water.
Ninakula matunda. — I eat fruits.

days.tip: “ch” is like “church.” Swahili consonants are generally crisp, not breathy.
days.culture: Sharing meals is social—offering food/water is a common sign of hospitality.

words.sentence: Niko nyumbani. — I am at home.
Tunaenda sokoni. — We are going to the market.
Watoto wako shule. — The children are at school.

days.tip: The “ny” sound is like Spanish “ñ” (canyon): nyumbani.
days.culture: Markets (soko) are central community hubs—food, news, and relationships all flow through them.

words.sentence: Nataka chai. — I want tea.
Nina pesa kidogo. — I have a little money.
Ninaenda nyumbani. — I am going home.

days.tip: Swahili packs meaning into prefixes. “Ni-” (I) is a powerful building block.
days.culture: Learning a few verb patterns lets you speak quickly even with a small vocabulary.

words.sentence: Geuka kushoto. — Turn left.
Nenda kulia. — Go right.
Enda mbele. — Go forward.

days.tip: “ku-” often marks an infinitive/directional form—here it’s part of fixed direction words.
days.culture: Giving directions is often relational (“near the big tree / by the shop”). These basics still help a lot.

words.sentence: Ninapenda rangi nyeusi. — I like the color black.
Bendera ina nyekundu. — The flag has red.
Kijani ni rangi ya mimea. — Green is the color of plants.

days.tip: Notice the repeated “nye-” in black/red. Don’t rush it—make it smooth.
days.culture: These colors connect to Pan-African symbolism; learning them in Swahili reinforces the cultural bridge.

words.sentence: Jamii yetu ni imara. — Our community is strong.
Umoja ni nguvu. — Unity is strength.
Tuna nguvu pamoja. — We have strength together.

days.tip: The “ng” at the start (nguvu) is like the ending of “song” but moved to the front.
days.culture: “Umoja” is a key principle in Kwanzaa and a cornerstone concept across African liberation movements.

words.sentence: Nina kazi leo. — I have work today.
Biashara hii ni nzuri. — This business is good.
Nahitaji pesa. — I need money.

days.tip: Stress is usually even in Swahili. Keep it rhythmic, not heavy like English stress patterns.
days.culture: Small businesses (biashara) are a major economic engine—supporting them is community-building.

words.sentence: Heshima ni muhimu. — Respect is important.
Tafakari kabla ya kuamua. — Reflect before you decide.
Amani iwe kwako. — Peace be with you.

days.tip: “kh/ k” sounds are clean. Don’t add extra breath—keep it crisp.
days.culture: Many greetings and blessings center peace (amani) and goodwill—language carries values.

words.sentence: Afya yangu ni nzuri. — My health is good.
Nahitaji dawa. — I need medicine.
Mazoezi ni muhimu. — Exercise is important.

days.tip: “oe” is two vowel sounds: ma-zo-e-zi (not ‘mzoezi’ as one clump).
days.culture: Wellness is holistic—movement, food, community, and spirit often connect in daily life.

words.sentence: Napenda kusoma. — I like to study.
Nataka kuelewa zaidi. — I want to understand more.
Lugha ni daraja. — Language is a bridge.

days.tip: “gh” in lugha is a soft throaty sound in some accents; many learners pronounce it like a light ‘g’—that’s okay.
days.culture: Swahili is a bridge language across East Africa—learning it connects regions and histories.

words.sentence: Chumba hiki ni kikubwa. — This room is big.
Funga mlango. — Close the door.
Fungua dirisha. — Open the window.

days.tip: Swahili allows consonant clusters like “ml-”. Say it smoothly: mlango.
days.culture: Homes often include extended family and guests—hospitality shapes how spaces are used.

words.sentence: Safari yangu ilikuwa nzuri. — My trip was good.
Nina gari. — I have a car.
Njia iko wapi? — Where is the way/road?

days.tip: “nj” is like ‘n’ + ‘j’ together (like ‘enjoy’ starting sound).
days.culture: “Safari” became global, but in Swahili it simply means journey—physical or symbolic.

words.sentence: Nina furaha leo. — I am happy today.
Ninahisi huzuni. — I feel sad.
Usiwe na hasira. — Don’t be angry.

days.tip: “h” is pronounced—don’t drop it like some English habits.
days.culture: Naming emotions directly can be seen as honest and grounding—tone and respect still matter.

words.sentence: Mti huu ni mrefu. — This tree is tall.
Bahari ni kubwa. — The ocean is big.
Jua linaangaza. — The sun is shining.

days.tip: Short words still keep clear vowels: jua = joo-ah (two beats).
days.culture: Swahili coastal culture is deeply tied to the sea (bahari) through trade, fishing, and history.

words.sentence: Roho yangu iko thabiti. — My spirit is strong.
Imani inaleta nguvu. — Faith brings strength.
Baraka kwako. — Blessings to you.

days.tip: Swahili is spoken by diverse faith communities; words like imani/baraka appear across contexts.
days.culture: Blessings and well-wishes are woven into everyday speech—language as spiritual care.

words.sentence: Lengo langu ni kujifunza. — My goal is to learn.
Tuko pamoja. — We are together.
Ushindi ni wetu. — Victory is ours.

days.tip: “sh” is like ‘shoe’. Keep the ‘u’ before it open: ushindi.
days.culture: Collective language (“pamoja”) reflects cooperative survival and celebration.

words.sentence: Nani huyo? — Who is that?
Uko wapi? — Where are you?
Kwa nini umechelewa? — Why are you late?

days.tip: Kwa nini is two words. Don’t smash it into one sound—keep it clear.
days.culture: Asking politely matters—tone + “tafadhali” can soften questions.

words.sentence: Asubuhi njema. — Good morning.
Mchana mwema. — Good afternoon.
Usiku mwema. — Good night.

days.tip: The “ch” again is like church. Mchana starts with m- + ch.
days.culture: Greetings change by time of day; using the right one shows care and awareness.

words.sentence: Asante kwa msaada. — Thank you for the help.
Tunaweza kufanya hivi. — We can do this.
Tushirikiane. — Let’s cooperate.

days.tip: Long words are just syllables in a row. Don’t panic—clap the rhythm if needed.
days.culture: Cooperation is a core survival strategy—language reinforces group identity and mutual aid.

words.sentence: Tunataka haki. — We want justice.
Ukweli ni muhimu. — Truth is important.
Upendo ni nguvu. — Love is strength.

days.tip: “kw” is a quick blend: uk-weli (not oo-koo-eli).
days.culture: These words show up in speeches, songs, and daily encouragement—values spoken become values lived.

words.sentence: Nina simu. — I have a phone.
Nimetuma ujumbe. — I sent a message.
Mtandao ni polepole. — The internet is slow.

days.tip: “nd” is blended: mtandao has a strong “nd” in the middle.
days.culture: Swahili adapts with technology—new words form while keeping the language’s rhythm.

words.sentence: Nataka chai, tafadhali. — I want tea, please.
Unapenda kahawa? — Do you like coffee?
Bei ni gani? — What is the price?

days.tip: Bei is two vowels: beh-ee. Don’t make it one long ‘bay’.
days.culture: Asking price politely is normal; bargaining can be part of friendly interaction in markets.

words.sentence: Ninakimbia asubuhi. — I run in the morning.
Tutembee pamoja. — Let’s walk together.
Ruka juu! — Jump up!

days.tip: Notice the pattern: -bea / -bia endings are syllables, not silent endings.
days.culture: Movement words show up in sports, dance, and daily life—Swahili rhythm pairs well with music.

words.sentence: Mimi ni mwanafunzi. — I am a student.
Wewe ni rafiki. — You are a friend.
Sisi ni familia. — We are family.

days.tip: These pronouns are clean and short—perfect for confidence-building practice.
days.culture: Identity can be individual and collective; language makes room for both.

words.sentence: Leo tuna sherehe. — Today we have a celebration.
Hongera kwa ushindi! — Congratulations on the victory!
Kumbuka: umoja ni nguvu. — Remember: unity is strength.

days.tip: If you can say day 30 smoothly, you’ve built real mouth-muscle memory. Keep going—repeat days in a loop.
days.culture: Celebration is community energy—music, dance, food, and story. Language keeps memory alive.
